text: This looks interesting, but I’m slightly disappointed that it uses Python. <http://introtodeeplearning.com>

attachments.title: MIT Deep Learning 6.S191
attachments.text: MIT's official introductory course on deep learning methods and applications.

elements.text: This looks interesting, but I’m slightly disappointed that it uses Python.

text: I wonder if they have plans to port it to Julia. Looks like they have lots of stuff.

elements.text: I wonder if they have plans to port it to Julia. Looks like they have lots of stuff.

text: Ha. Looking at the sponsors, I doubt the course will be in Julia any time soon.

elements.text: Ha. Looking at the sponsors, I doubt the course will be in Julia any time soon.

text: Well, it is what it is. It looks like I need to follow this as well.

elements.text: Well, it is what it is. It looks like I need to follow this as well.

text: makes you wonder how much money they make being MIT professors(400k/yr ish), then getting NVIDIA, Google, etc sponsoring the recordings of some lectures lol.

elements.text: makes you wonder how much money they make being MIT professors(400k/yr ish), then getting NVIDIA, Google, etc sponsoring the recordings of some lectures lol.
likely hardware access for students

text: But yea I mean, if you sponsor a class, and the students use your technology, you can pretty much guarantee they will use those tools in industry/research later. So it's a smart move.

elements.text: But yea I mean, if you sponsor a class, and the students use your technology, you can pretty much guarantee they will use those tools in industry/research later. So it's a smart move.

text: Using python however, not a smart move.

elements.text: Using python however, not a smart move.
But a safe move.

text: True, I mean if you end up leaving MIT going to Google, or anywhere else really, high chance you'll be using python.
